elements.content: Reaction of 4,4′,4″-{[(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl)tris(methylene)]tris(oxy)}tribenzoic acid (H3TCM) with Mn2+, Cu2+, and Co2+ salts afforded four interesting metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Mn2(TCM)Cl(H2O)3]·3DMF·3CH3OH (1), [Mn4(TCM)2(CH3COO)2(DMF)5]·4CH3OH (2), [Cu2(TCM)(CH3COO)(DMF)(H2O)]·2DMF·3CH3OH (3) and [Co3(TCM)2(H2O)5]·5DMF·3CH3OH (4). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the four structures based on the flexible TCM tripod consist of honeycomb lattices with different metal–ligand macrocycles. The assembly of the metal–ligand macrocycles and framework topologies is dependent on the coordination geometries of transition metal cations. The two-dimensional coordination network of 1 was further connected by an auxiliary acetate ligand to give rise to a three-dimensional honeycomb network of 2. The TCM ligand centered photoluminescences of these compounds are very sensitive to the coordination modes of the TCM ligands, the metal secondary building units (SBUs), and their microstructures. These MOFs also present interesting magnetic behaviors, as revealed by the study of the magnetic susceptibilities.

elements.content: The connection of a flexible tripodal polyaromatic acid with various metal cations of MnII, CuII, and CoII gives rise to four interesting metal−organic frameworks that present interesting photoluminescent and magnetic properties. The assembly of the metal−ligand macrocycles and their honeycomb frameworks is dependent on the coordination geometries of metal cations, as the conformation of the flexible ligand is variable.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As an emerging class of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained much attention in a number of fields ranging from gas adsorption, separation and storage, catalysis, drug delivery, and biomedical imaging. MOF materials have advantages over the conventional inorganic porous materials in that the frameworks and functionalities of MOF materials can be systematically and predictably modulated via modification of the constituent elements. It is particularly feasible for the MOFs that are constructed from rigid organic linkers connected with metal secondary building units (SBUs).

elements.content: Due to their conformational freedom, the flexible organic ligands are not capable of stabilizing the high porous frameworks with very large channels. Such framework structures are unpredictable and variable because the connection between flexible ligands and metal cations depends upon the rotation freedom and flexibility of organic moieties, the coordination polyhedra of metal nodes, and the synthesis conditions. On the other hand, the connection character frequently produces MOF materials with unusual framework topologies and unique properties. However, the conformational freedom of the flexible ligands makes it more difficult to synthesize and control the crystalline coordination networks in the self-assembly process.

However, the conformational freedom of the flexible ligands makes it more difficult to synthesize and control the crystalline coordination networks in the self-assembly process.

elements.clean_text: 1  H3BTB and H3TCM

elements.content: To understand the coordination ability of the flexible ligands and the structure–property relationship of such MOF materials, we designed 4,4′,4″-{[(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl)tris(methylene)]tris(oxy)}tribenzoic acid (H3TCM) that contains three benzoic acid groups that have greater conformational freedom compared to the more well-studied benzene tribenzoic acid (H3BTB), as shown in Scheme . We expected that the new tripodal polyaromatic acid might combine with various metal SBUs for the formation of some interesting MOF materials by converging the characters of the rigid BTB ligand and the conformational freedom of the flexible organic moieties. Herein, we report the synthesis, structures, and properties of four MOF materials, [Mn2(TCM)­Cl­(H2O)3]·­3DMF·­3CH3OH (1), [Mn4(TCM)2­(CH3COO)2­(DMF)5]·­4CH3OH (2), [Cu2(TCM)­(CH3COO)­(DMF)­(H2O)]·­2DMF·­3CH3OH (3), and [Co3(TCM)2­(H2O)5]·­5DMF·­3CH3OH (4). The X-ray diffraction results clearly demonstrate that the coordination modes of the TCM ligand are flexible and variable, depending on the connecting metal SBUs for the formation of interesting metal–ligand macrocycles. The photoluminescent emission intensities and band positions of these compounds are also flexible and variable, depending on their framework structures and metal SBUs. The temperature dependent molar magnetic susceptibilities of compounds 1–4 were also studied and analyzed.

The X-ray diffraction results clearly demonstrate that the coordination modes of the TCM ligand are flexible and variable, depending on the connecting metal SBUs for the formation of interesting metal-ligand macrocycles. elements.content: All of the chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification, except 1,3,5-tris(bromomethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene was prepared according to the literature. FTIR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a FTS-40 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction data (PXRD) were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2550/PC for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under N2 atmosphere on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Solid state fluorescent spectra were recorded on a HITACHI F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The ground solid crystalline samples (5 mg) were sealed in a 2 × 5 mm2 flat quartz cylinder cell. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 400 V and the scan speed was 240 nm min–1, while the slit widths of excitation and emission spectra are both 2.5 nm. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS(SQUID)-XL magnetometer. Elemental analysis was performed on a ThermoFinnigan Flash EA 1112 element analyzer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a 500 MHz spectrometer in CDCl3 or d 6-DMSO solution, and the chemical shifts were reported relative to the internal standard, TMS (0 ppm). The following abbreviations are used to describe peak patterns where appropriate: s = singlet and d = doublet.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All of the chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification, except 1,3,5-tris(bromomethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene was prepared according to the literature. FTIR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a FTS-40 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction data (PXRD) were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2550/PC for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under N2 atmosphere on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Solid state fluorescent spectra were recorded on a HITACHI F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The ground solid crystalline samples (5 mg) were sealed in a 2 × 5 mm2 flat quartz cylinder cell. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 400 V and the scan speed was 240 nm min-1, while the slit widths of excitation and emission spectra are both 2.5 nm. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS(SQUID)-XL magnetometer. Elemental analysis was performed on a ThermoFinnigan Flash EA 1112 element analyzer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a 500 MHz spectrometer in CDCl3 or d 6-DMSO solution, and the chemical shifts were reported relative to the internal standard, TMS (0 ppm). The following abbreviations are used to describe peak patterns where appropriate: s = singlet and d = doublet.

elements.clean_text: 2  Synthesis Route for H3TCM

elements.content: As shown in Scheme , a mixture of 1,3,5-tris(bromomethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene (1.14 g, 3.0 mmol), methyl-4-hydroxybenzoate (1.52 g, 10.0 mmol), and K2CO3 (1.382 g, 10 mmol) in 50 mL of acetone was refluxed for 6 h. The mixture was subsequently filtered and cooled to room temperature. White crystalline solid Me3TCM was collected by filtration. Yield: 1.47 g (80%). Mp: 208.1–208.3 °C. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.04 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 6H), 7.04 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 6H), 5.16 (s, 6H), 3.90 (s, 9H), 2.44 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 167.0, 163.0, 139.9, 131.9, 131.6, 123.2, 114.4, 65.3, 52.2, 16.2. Anal. Calcd for Me3TCM (%): C, 70.57; H, 5.92; found, C, 70.46; H, 5.96.

elements.content: The unit cell determinations and data collections for the crystals of compounds 1–4 were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Ultra diffractometer with an Atlas detector. The data were collected using graphite–monochromatic enhanced ultra Cu radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 293 K. The data sets were corrected by empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures of all compounds were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELX-97. As the solvent molecules in these compounds are highly disordered, the SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suit was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered guest molecules. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures. H atoms on C atoms were generated geometrically. The data collection parameters, crystallographic data, and final agreement factors are collected in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Data Collections and Structure Determinations

The unit cell determinations and data collections for the crystals of compounds 1-4 were performed on an Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Ultra diffractometer with an Atlas detector. The data were collected using graphite-monochromatic enhanced ultra Cu radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 293 K. The data sets were corrected by empirical absorption correction using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures of all compounds were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELX-97. As the solvent molecules in these compounds are highly disordered, the SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suit was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered guest molecules. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures. H atoms on C atoms were generated geometrically. The data collection parameters, crystallographic data, and final agreement factors are collected in Table .

The formation of the crystalline solids of 1–4 is very sensitive to the reaction conditions. We tried to synthesize the crystals of 1–4 in single solvents, such as methanol and DMF. However, no solid sample was produced in the DMF solvent, while the precipitate was formed in methanol. When the reaction was performed at room temperature, no solid product can be isolated, while higher temperatures can not generate good crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The reproducibility and phase purity of the bulky samples of 1–4 were confirmed by FTIR and PXRD. The compositions of the as-synthesized compounds 1–4 were figured out based on the elemental analysis, TGA, and single crystal structures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The formation of the crystalline solids of 1-4 is very sensitive to the reaction conditions. We tried to synthesize the crystals of 1-4 in single solvents, such as methanol and DMF. However, no solid sample was produced in the DMF solvent, while the precipitate was formed in methanol. When the reaction was performed at room temperature, no solid product can be isolated, while higher temperatures can not generate good crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The reproducibility and phase purity of the bulky samples of 1-4 were confirmed by FTIR and PXRD. The compositions of the as-synthesized compounds 1-4 were figured out based on the elemental analysis, TGA, and single crystal structures.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group. There are two crystallographically independent MnII cations, one TCM ligand, one chloride anion, and three water ligands in the asymmetric unit. The first MnII cation coordinates to three carboxyl oxygen atoms of three TCM ligands [Mn–O = 2.010(5)–2.159(7) Å] and one chloride anion [Mn–Cl = 2.352(3) Å] in slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figure a). The second MnII cation octahedrally coordinates to three carboxyl oxygen atoms of three TCM ligands [Mn–O = 2.011(9)–2.227(15) Å] and three water molecules [Mn–O = 1.951(10)-2.430(8) Å]. The two MnII cations are coupled in pair by the three carboxylate groups to form a binuclear Mn2(COO)3 ({Mn2}) SBU. The TCM ligand acts as a μ6-bridge to link three {Mn2} SBUs together, in which each carboxylate group adopts a μ-bridging mode. It is interesting that the {Mn2} SBUs are linked by TCM ligands to give rise to a two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb lamellar network with hexagonal-shaped cavities (Figure b). The cross dimension of the 60-membered macrocycle is 22.8 Å. The central benzene ring of TCM is approximately rotated by 60° to the central benzene ring of TCM in the neighboring sheet (Figure c). As a result, each honeycomb layer is offset from the next layer by approximately half of the hexagonal width to form an interesting supramolecular network (Figure d). TGA showed that a weight loss of 34.0% occurred between 25 and 318 °C, corresponding to the loss of water, DMF, and CH3OH molecules (expected 34.1%).

elements.content: The shortest Mn...Mn distance between two alternative layers is 5.79 Å in 1, which suggests that the manganese(II) cations can be further connected by suitable bridging groups for the formation of a three-dimensional (3D) coordination network with nanotubular channels. We have therefore used Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O instead of MnCl2·4H2O in the presence of acetic acid under the identical synthesis conditions of 1, which afforded light brown crystals of 2 after two days. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic P̅1 space group, which consists of four MnII cations, two TCM ligands, two acetates, and five DMF ligands in the asymmetric unit. Similar to 1, two octahedrally coordinated MnII cations are coupled in pair by three carboxylate groups to form a binuclear {Mn2} SBU [Mn–O = 2.066(6)–2.431(5) Å], while the remaining coordination sites are occupied by DMF molecules [Mn–O = 2.172(7)–2.244(5) Å; Figure a]. It is interesting that two binuclear {Mn2} SBUs between the two alternative sheets are connected by an acetate [Mn–O = 2.202(5)–2.431(5) Å] to give rise to a manganese-carboxylate chain network (Figure b). As a consequence, an interesting 3D coordination network with 1D nanotubular subunits (18.1 × 20.6 Å2) was generated (Figure c). To avoid a very large vacant space, compound 2 comprises 2-fold interpenetration (Figure d). TGA showed that a weight loss of 25.0% occurred between 25 and 290 °C, corresponding to the loss of DMF and CH3OH molecules (expected 25.1%).

elements.content: When Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O was used instead of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O under the same synthesis conditions of 2, compound 3 was isolated as green crystals. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P̅1 space group. There are two copper(II) cations, one TCM, one acetate, one water, and one DMF ligands in the asymmetric unit. The first CuII cation coordinates to four TCM carboxyl oxygen atoms [Cu–O = 1.928(7)–1.970(7) Å] and one water ligand [Cu–O = 2.290(7) Å] in square pyramidal geometry (cyan square pyramids in Figure a), while the second CuII cation coordinates by a square pyramidal geometry to three TCM [Cu–O = 1.957(6)–1.966(7) Å], one acetate carboxyl oxygen atom [Cu–O = 1.913(7)-1.962(8) Å], and one DMF molecule [Cu–O = 2.166(6) Å; purple square pyramids in Figure a]. The two kinds of CuII cations are respectively coupled by four carboxylate groups of four TCM ligands or three carboxylate groups of three TCM ligands and one acetate to form two kinds of paddlewheel binuclear Cu2(COO)4 SBUs with the Cu···Cu distances ranging from 2.600(3) to 2.611(3) Å. The relative long distance between CuII and the apical water or DMF ligand should be ascribed to the Jahn–Teller effect. Calculations with the method developed by Addison gave the τ value of 0.01, which suggests that the coordination geometry of copper(II) cations is almost the perfect square pyramid. The Cu2(COO)4 SBUs are connected by TCM ligands to form two kinds of macrocycles, an 80-membered macrocycle (12.08 × 35.22 Å2) and a 40-membered macrocycle (7.50 × 15.29 Å2). The macrocycles further propagate and extend to form a lamellar network, by sharing the Cu2(COO)4 SBU corners and TCM central benzene rings (Figure b). The neighboring grids are connected by van der Waals interactions (Figure c). As a result, the 3D supramolecular network of 3 contains 1D opening channels with dimensions of 12.92 × 16.66 Å2, along the a axis (Figure d). TGA showed that a weight loss of 31.2% occurred between 25 and 268 °C, corresponding to the loss of water, DMF, and CH3OH molecules (expected 31.2%).

elements.content: The reaction between H3TCM and cobalt nitrate afforded pink crystals of 4 that crystallize in the triclinic P̅1 space group. When cobalt acetate is taken in place of cobalt nitrate, only an unknown precipitate was formed under the same reaction conditions. The coordination modes of TCM ligands and the coordination environments of CoII cations are different from in the above-discussed compounds. There are three CoII cations, two TCM ligands, and five aqua ligands in the asymmetric unit. The TCM ligands act as tetradentate and hexadentate ligands to connect with four and six CoII cations, respectively (Figure a). Each TCM ligand independently links up a symmetrically independent CoII cation to form a 60-membered macrocycle and further propagates into a honeycomb sheet (Figure b). The CoII cations comprise three kinds of octahedral coordination geometry (Figure c). The first CoII cation coordinates to two chelated carboxylate groups [Co–O = 2.009(11)–2.457(9) Å], a carboxyl oxygen atom [Co–O = 1.994(9) Å], and one aqua ligand [Co–O = 2.026(8) Å; purple octahedra in Figure ]; the second CoII cation coordinates to four carboxyl oxygens of three TCM ligands [Co–O = 1.976(13)–2.219(7) Å] and two water molecules [Co–O = 2.062(8)–2.304(15) Å; cyan octahedra in Figure ]. The two CoII cations, respectively, act as connecting nodes in the two independent hexagonal grids. The third CoII cation connects with two CoII cations by coordinating to four carboxyl oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups [Co–O = 2.024(9)–2.172(9) Å] and two water molecules [Co–O = 2.112(9)–2.191(10) Å; orange octahedra in Figure ] to give rise to a trinuclear Co3(COO)6 SBU. As a result, two independent lattices are joined together by the third kind of CoII cations to form an interesting double-layered honeycomb sheet (Figure d). To avoid a very large vacant space, the 3D supramolecular network of 4 is interpenetrated by interlocking the grid networks (Figure ). TGA showed that a weight loss of 28.6% occurred between 25 and 330 °C, corresponding to the loss of water, DMF, and CH3OH molecules (expected 29.6%).

elements.content: It is valuable to make comparisons with the MOFs that are constructed from the similar conformational organic ligands, such as rigid 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3BTB and flexible 1,3,5-benzenetriacetic acid (H3BTA) ligands. Given the metal clustered SBUs and the coordination modes of the ligands are almost identical; however, their frameworks are significantly different. It has been well-known that the formation of coordination frameworks is propending to form less vacant space in nature. However, the coordination driving force leads to high porous MOF materials with very large cavities in the case of BTB. This is because the free rotation of the single bonds (purple bonds in Figure ) in BTB can not let the carboxylate C atoms much deviate from the central benzene plane (the maximum deviation angle is ±10.5°). For the flexible ligands, such as BTA and TCM, the deviation angles of the carboxylate C atoms from the central benzene plane are variable and dependent on the connection between metal cations and organic ligands. The maximum deviation angle can reach up to ±40.4 and ±33.2° for BTA and TCM, respectively. Moreover, the different orientations of the carboxylate groups toward the benzene plane will generate more complicated conformations of the flexible ligands. Hence, the porosity and the topology of such MOF materials are not predictable, as the freedom of rotation and the twist of flexibility of organic moieties play very important roles on the formation of different coordination networks.

elements.content: As demonstrated already, the photoluminescences of MOF materials are very sensitive to their framework structures, while the flexible ligands have the ability to construct various coordination networks depending on the metal nodes. The multiple chromophores and auxochromes in the TCM ligand encouraged the study of emission behaviors of compounds 1–4. For reliable comparison, we used the same quantity of solid crystalline samples under the same conditions. Moreover, the luminescent spectrum of H3TCM was also measured under the same conditions. H3TCM exhibits broad fluorescent emission upon excitation at 380 nm in the solid-state at room temperature (Figure ). Upon excitement at the same conditions, the fluorescent emission of compound 1 is blue shifted with the emission peak at 438 nm. When the grid lamellar network of 1 was transferred into the 3D honeycomb framework of compound 2, an additional emission band appears at 417 nm beside the band at 441 nm. Interestingly, the emission is significantly enhanced, which suggests that the more intense 3D framework can restrain the nonradiative energy decay. Compared with compounds 1 and 2, the emission of compound 4 is weakened with an emission band at 436 nm. Compound 3 exhibits nonluminescent behavior, indicating that the energy is mainly transferred in a nonradiative process. Because there is no obvious absorption peak in the luminescent region for the MnII, CuII, and CoII cations (see Figure S10 of the ), the photoluminescent emissions of compounds 1, 2, and 4 should be arisen from the π→π* or π→n* transitions of the TCM ligand. The emission intensities of these MOFs are greatly dependent on the intensity of their framework structures, while the blue-shift emissions for 1, 2, and 4 should be attributed to the coordination of the carboxylate groups to the metal cations, which can affect the energy levels of the TCM ligand.

elements.content: The variations of the molar magnetic susceptibilities χM of compounds 1–4 were investigated on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 2.0–300 K with an applied field of 1000 Oe. At 300 K, the χM T value is 8.375 cm3 K mol–1 for compound 1 (Figure ). The experimental value is slightly lower than the expected value for the spin-only ground state (g = 2) of two manganese(II) cations (8.75 cm3 K mol–1). The χM T value decreases gradually to a minimum of 0.7098 cm3 K mol–1 when the temperature was lowered to 2.0 K, which is a characteristic antiferromagnetic behavior. To evaluate the magnetic interaction between MnII cations, the experimental data were quantitatively analyzed by treating it as an interacting dimer, while the exchange through the TCM bridges was taken as an interdimer molecular field (Eq and ). χ dimer = ( 2 N g 2 β 2 k T ) ( e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + 14 e 12 J / k T + 30 e 20 J / k T + 55 e 30 J / k T 1 + 3 e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + 7 e 12 J / k T + 9 e 20 J / k T + 11 e 30 J / k T ) χ M = χ dim ⁡ e r / [ 1 − χ dim ⁡ e r ( 2 zJ ′ / Ng 2 μ B 2 ) + TIP In eq and , J is the intradimer exchange constant; zJ′ is the interdimer coupling constant transferred by TCM ligands, and TIP is the temperature-independent paramagnetism. Least-square fitting of all experimental data leads to the J = −0.755 cm–1, zJ′ = −0.585 cm–1, g = 2.05, and TIP = −1.09 × 10–3 cm3 K mol–1 with an agreement factor of R = 3.10 × 10–4. These small and negative exchange constant values demonstrate that the interaction between the MnII centers is weakly antiferromagnetic.

elements.content: Figure shows the magnetic behavior of compound 3, in the forms of χMT versus T and χM versus T plots. At 300 K, the χM T value per dimer is 0.7657 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly higher than that expected for an isolated paramagnetic system (0.75 cm3 K mol–1). Upon cooling, the magnetic moment drops smoothly to an inflection point value of 0.1982 cm3 K mol–1 at 55 K and further drops abruptly to a value of 0.1078 cm3 K mol–1 at 51 K, followed by another smooth drop to 0.0248 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The overall drop could be considered a result of antiferromagnetic exchange mediated by four carboxylate bridges. The presence of the inflection point suggests that phase transformations might occur at the stage. We analyzed the variable temperature susceptibility data in the temperature range of 300–355 K by using a dimer model (eq 2). χ dimer = N g 2 μ B 2 S ( S + 1 ) ( 1 + u ) / 3 k T u = coth [ J S ( S + 1 ) / k T ] − k T / J S ( S + 1 ) χ M = χ dimer / [ 1 − χ dimer ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 μ B 2 ) + TIP ] In eq 2, J is the intradimer exchange constant and zJ′ is the interdimer coupling constant transferred by TCM ligands; TIP is the temperature-independent paramagnetism. The best fit for χM T versus T in the range of 55–300 K (solid line shown in Figure ) leads to the following parameters: J = −231.705 cm–1, zJ′ = −1.122 cm–1, g = 2.01713, TIP = 8.44 × 10–3 cm3 K mol–1, and R = 2.0 × 10–5. These results suggest the existence of strong antiferromagnetic interactions between the two copper(II) centers of the dimer unit and of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent dimer units. The short-range strong antiferromagnetic correlation and long-range weak antiferromagnetic interaction present in the system are slightly higher than that of previously reported copper(II) acetate and other dinuclear copper(II) carboxylates (−143 ∼ −220 cm–1), where the copper(II) cations are bridged by four carboxylate groups with shorter Cu(II)···Cu(II) distance of about 2.60 Å.

elements.content: In summary, we designed and synthesized a new flexible tripodal polyaromatic acid (H3TCM) ligand for the construction of four interesting metal–organic coordination networks. Due to the flexible nature of the TCM ligand and the variable coordination modes of the metal SBUs, structures of these compounds are differing in the metal–ligand macrocycles and framework topologies that are dependent on the coordination geometries of transition metal cations. Moreover, the 2D framework structure of the coordination network of 1 can be transferred into the 3D honeycomb network of 2, in the presence of an auxiliary acetate ligand. Such a transformation can subsequently enhance the photoluminescent emission of 2. From the magnetic experiments, we observed some interesting magnetic behaviors of these coordination compounds. Further studies on the breathing and recognition ability of these MOF materials in the presence of various small molecules are underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we designed and synthesized a new flexible tripodal polyaromatic acid (H3TCM) ligand for the construction of four interesting metal-organic coordination networks. Due to the flexible nature of the TCM ligand and the variable coordination modes of the metal SBUs, structures of these compounds are differing in the metal-ligand macrocycles and framework topologies that are dependent on the coordination geometries of transition metal cations. Moreover, the 2D framework structure of the coordination network of 1 can be transferred into the 3D honeycomb network of 2, in the presence of an auxiliary acetate ligand. Such a transformation can subsequently enhance the photoluminescent emission of 2. From the magnetic experiments, we observed some interesting magnetic behaviors of these coordination compounds. Further studies on the breathing and recognition ability of these MOF materials in the presence of various small molecules are underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
When Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O was used instead of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O under the same synthesis conditions of 2, compound 3 was isolated as green crystals. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P̅1 space group. There are two copper(II) cations, one TCM, one acetate, one water, and one DMF ligands in the asymmetric unit. The first CuII cation coordinates to four TCM carboxyl oxygen atoms [Cu–O = 1.928(7)–1.970(7) Å] and one water ligand [Cu–O = 2.290(7) Å] in square pyramidal geometry (cyan square pyramids in Figure a), while the second CuII cation coordinates by a square pyramidal geometry to three TCM [Cu–O = 1.957(6)–1.966(7) Å], one acetate carboxyl oxygen atom [Cu–O = 1.913(7)-1.962(8) Å], and one DMF molecule [Cu–O = 2.166(6) Å; purple square pyramids in Figure a]. The two kinds of CuII cations are respectively coupled by four carboxylate groups of four TCM ligands or three carboxylate groups of three TCM ligands and one acetate to form two kinds of paddlewheel binuclear Cu2(COO)4 SBUs with the Cu···Cu distances ranging from 2.600(3) to 2.611(3) Å. The relative long distance between CuII and the apical water or DMF ligand should be ascribed to the Jahn–Teller effect. Calculations with the method developed by Addison gave the τ value of 0.01, which suggests that the coordination geometry of copper(II) cations is almost the perfect square pyramid. The Cu2(COO)4 SBUs are connected by TCM ligands to form two kinds of macrocycles, an 80-membered macrocycle (12.08 × 35.22 Å2) and a 40-membered macrocycle (7.50 × 15.29 Å2). The macrocycles further propagate and extend to form a lamellar network, by sharing the Cu2(COO)4 SBU corners and TCM central benzene rings (Figure b). The neighboring grids are connected by van der Waals interactions (Figure c). As a result, the 3D supramolecular network of 3 contains 1D opening channels with dimensions of 12.92 × 16.66 Å2, along the a axis (Figure d). TGA showed that a weight loss of 31.2% occurred between 25 and 268 °C, corresponding to the loss of water, DMF, and CH3OH molecules (expected 31.2%).

The reaction between H3TCM and cobalt nitrate afforded pink crystals of 4 that crystallize in the triclinic P̅1 space group. When cobalt acetate is taken in place of cobalt nitrate, only an unknown precipitate was formed under the same reaction conditions. The coordination modes of TCM ligands and the coordination environments of CoII cations are different from in the above-discussed compounds. There are three CoII cations, two TCM ligands, and five aqua ligands in the asymmetric unit. The TCM ligands act as tetradentate and hexadentate ligands to connect with four and six CoII cations, respectively (Figure a). Each TCM ligand independently links up a symmetrically independent CoII cation to form a 60-membered macrocycle and further propagates into a honeycomb sheet (Figure b). The CoII cations comprise three kinds of octahedral coordination geometry (Figure c). The first CoII cation coordinates to two chelated carboxylate groups [Co–O = 2.009(11)–2.457(9) Å], a carboxyl oxygen atom [Co–O = 1.994(9) Å], and one aqua ligand [Co–O = 2.026(8) Å; purple octahedra in Figure ]; the second CoII cation coordinates to four carboxyl oxygens of three TCM ligands [Co–O = 1.976(13)–2.219(7) Å] and two water molecules [Co–O = 2.062(8)–2.304(15) Å; cyan octahedra in Figure ]. The two CoII cations, respectively, act as connecting nodes in the two independent hexagonal grids. The third CoII cation connects with two CoII cations by coordinating to four carboxyl oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups [Co–O = 2.024(9)–2.172(9) Å] and two water molecules [Co–O = 2.112(9)–2.191(10) Å; orange octahedra in Figure ] to give rise to a trinuclear Co3(COO)6 SBU. As a result, two independent lattices are joined together by the third kind of CoII cations to form an interesting double-layered honeycomb sheet (Figure d). To avoid a very large vacant space, the 3D supramolecular network of 4 is interpenetrated by interlocking the grid networks (Figure ). TGA showed that a weight loss of 28.6% occurred between 25 and 330 °C, corresponding to the loss of water, DMF, and CH3OH molecules (expected 29.6%).

Figure shows the magnetic behavior of compound 3, in the forms of χMT versus T and χM versus T plots. At 300 K, the χM T value per dimer is 0.7657 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly higher than that expected for an isolated paramagnetic system (0.75 cm3 K mol–1). Upon cooling, the magnetic moment drops smoothly to an inflection point value of 0.1982 cm3 K mol–1 at 55 K and further drops abruptly to a value of 0.1078 cm3 K mol–1 at 51 K, followed by another smooth drop to 0.0248 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The overall drop could be considered a result of antiferromagnetic exchange mediated by four carboxylate bridges. The presence of the inflection point suggests that phase transformations might occur at the stage. We analyzed the variable temperature susceptibility data in the temperature range of 300–355 K by using a dimer model (eq 2). χ dimer = N g 2 μ B 2 S ( S + 1 ) ( 1 + u ) / 3 k T u = coth [ J S ( S + 1 ) / k T ] − k T / J S ( S + 1 ) χ M = χ dimer / [ 1 − χ dimer ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 μ B 2 ) + TIP ] In eq 2, J is the intradimer exchange constant and zJ′ is the interdimer coupling constant transferred by TCM ligands; TIP is the temperature-independent paramagnetism. The best fit for χM T versus T in the range of 55–300 K (solid line shown in Figure ) leads to the following parameters: J = −231.705 cm–1, zJ′ = −1.122 cm–1, g = 2.01713, TIP = 8.44 × 10–3 cm3 K mol–1, and R = 2.0 × 10–5. These results suggest the existence of strong antiferromagnetic interactions between the two copper(II) centers of the dimer unit and of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent dimer units. The short-range strong antiferromagnetic correlation and long-range weak antiferromagnetic interaction present in the system are slightly higher than that of previously reported copper(II) acetate and other dinuclear copper(II) carboxylates (−143 ∼ −220 cm–1), where the copper(II) cations are bridged by four carboxylate groups with shorter Cu(II)···Cu(II) distance of about 2.60 Å.

At 300 K, the χM T value is 1.0968 cm3 K mol–1 for compound 4 (Figure ). The experimental value is very close to that expected for three S = 1/2 spin cobalt(II) cations (1.125 cm3 K mol–1). The χM T value decreases gradually to a minimum of 0.4211 cm3 K mol–1 when temperature was lowered to 2.0 K, which is characteristic antiferromagnetic behavior. The χM –1 versus T plot could be fit with the Curie–Weiss equation in the all temperature ranges, yielding C = 1.137 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −7.767 K.
